Exercise 3.2.1

The purpose of this exercise is to demonstrate a concrete relationship between continuity and pointwise convergence, and between uniform continuity and uniform convergence. Let f ⁣:R→R\func{f}{\R}{\R}f:R→R be a function. For any a∈Ra \in \Ra∈R, let fa ⁣:R→R\func{f_a}{\R}{\R}fa​:R→R be the shifted function fa(x)≔f(x−a)f_a\p{x} \coloneqq f\p{x - a}fa​(x):=f(x−a).

  1. Show that fff is continuous if and only if, whenever (an)n=0∞\p{a_n}_{n=0}^\infty(an​)n=0∞​ is a sequence of real numbers which converges to zero, the shifted functions fanf_{a_n}fan​​ converge pointwise to fff.
  2. Show that fff is uniformly continuous if and only if, whenever (an)n=0∞\p{a_n}_{n=0}^\infty(an​)n=0∞​ is a sequence of real numbers which converges to zero, the shifted functions fanf_{a_n}fan​​ converge uniformly to fff.
Solution.

  1.   ⟹  \implies⟹:

    Suppose fff is continuous and let (an)n=1∞\p{a_n}_{n=1}^\infty(an​)n=1∞​ be a sequence which converges to 000. Let ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0 and x0∈Rx_0 \in \Rx0​∈R. Since fff is continuous at x0x_0x0​, there exists δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 (which depends on x0x_0x0​) such that

    ∀x∈R:∣x−x0∣<δ  ⟹  ∣f(x)−f(x0)∣<ε.\forall x \in \R : \abs{x - x_0} < \delta \implies \abs{f\p{x} - f\p{x_0}} < \varepsilon.∀x∈R:∣x−x0​∣<δ⟹∣f(x)−f(x0​)∣<ε.

    Since an→0a_n \to 0an​→0, there exists N∈NN \in \NN∈N such that

    n≥N  ⟹  ∣an∣<δ.n \geq N \implies \abs{a_n} < \delta.n≥N⟹∣an​∣<δ.

    In particular, if n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, then

    ∣(x0−an)−x0∣=∣an∣<δ.\abs{\p{x_0 - a_n} - x_0} = \abs{a_n} < \delta.∣(x0​−an​)−x0​∣=∣an​∣<δ.

    Thus,

    ∣fan(x0)−f(x0)∣=∣f(x0−an)−f(x0)∣<ε\abs{f_{a_n}\p{x_0} - f\p{x_0}} = \abs{f\p{x_0 - a_n} - f\p{x_0}} < \varepsilon∣fan​​(x0​)−f(x0​)∣=∣f(x0​−an​)−f(x0​)∣<ε

    for n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N. Since x0x_0x0​ and ε\varepsilonε were arbitrary, this shows that fan→ff_{a_n} \to ffan​​→f pointwise.

      ⟸  \impliedby⟸:

    Suppose fff were not continuous. Then

    ∃x0∈R ∃ε0>0 ∀δ>0 ∃x∈R:∣x−x0∣<δ but ∣f(x)−f(x0)∣≥ε0.\exists x_0 \in \R\ \exists \varepsilon_0 > 0\ \forall \delta > 0\ \exists x \in \R : \abs{x - x_0} < \delta \text{ but } \abs{f\p{x} - f\p{x_0}} \geq \varepsilon_0.∃x0​∈R ∃ε0​>0 ∀δ>0 ∃x∈R:∣x−x0​∣<δ but ∣f(x)−f(x0​)∣≥ε0​.

    Let x0∈Rx_0 \in \Rx0​∈R and ε0>0\varepsilon_0 > 0ε0​>0 be as in the negation. Applying the assumption to δ=1n\delta = \frac{1}{n}δ=n1​, we get a sequence (xn)n\p{x_n}_n(xn​)n​ such that ∣xn−x0∣<1n\abs{x_n - x_0} < \frac{1}{n}∣xn​−x0​∣<n1​ and ∣f(xn)−f(x0)∣≥ε0\abs{f\p{x_n} - f\p{x_0}} \geq \varepsilon_0∣f(xn​)−f(x0​)∣≥ε0​ for all n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N.

    By the squeeze theorem, an≔x0−xn→0a_n \coloneqq x_0 - x_n \to 0an​:=x0​−xn​→0, but

    ∣fan(x0)−f(x0)∣=∣f(xn)−f(x0)∣≥ε0,\abs{f_{a_n}\p{x_0} - f\p{x_0}} = \abs{f\p{x_n} - f\p{x_0}} \geq \varepsilon_0,∣fan​​(x0​)−f(x0​)∣=∣f(xn​)−f(x0​)∣≥ε0​,

    so fanf_{a_n}fan​​ does not converge to fff at x0x_0x0​.

  2.   ⟹  \implies⟹:

    Suppose fff is uniformly continuous and let (an)n=1∞\p{a_n}_{n=1}^\infty(an​)n=1∞​ be a sequence which converges to 000. Let ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0. Since fff is uniformly continuous, there exists δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 such that

    ∀x,y∈R:∣x−y∣<δ  ⟹  ∣f(x)−f(y)∣<ε.\forall x, y \in \R : \abs{x - y} < \delta \implies \abs{f\p{x} - f\p{y}} < \varepsilon.∀x,y∈R:∣x−y∣<δ⟹∣f(x)−f(y)∣<ε.

    Since an→0a_n \to 0an​→0, there exists N∈NN \in \NN∈N such that

    n≥N  ⟹  ∣an∣<δ.n \geq N \implies \abs{a_n} < \delta.n≥N⟹∣an​∣<δ.

    In particular, if n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N and x0∈Rx_0 \in \Rx0​∈R, then

    ∣(x0−an)−x0∣=∣an∣<δ.\abs{\p{x_0 - a_n} - x_0} = \abs{a_n} < \delta.∣(x0​−an​)−x0​∣=∣an​∣<δ.

    Thus, since x0x_0x0​ was arbitrary,

    ∀x0∈R:∣fan(x0)−f(x0)∣=∣f(x0−an)−f(x0)∣<ε\forall x_0 \in \R : \abs{f_{a_n}\p{x_0} - f\p{x_0}} = \abs{f\p{x_0 - a_n} - f\p{x_0}} < \varepsilon∀x0​∈R:∣fan​​(x0​)−f(x0​)∣=∣f(x0​−an​)−f(x0​)∣<ε

    for n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N. Since ε\varepsilonε was arbitrary, this shows that fan→ff_{a_n} \to ffan​​→f uniformly.

      ⟸  \impliedby⟸:

    Suppose fff were not uniformly continuous. Then

    ∃ε0>0 ∀δ>0 ∃x,y∈R:∣x−y∣<δ but ∣f(x)−f(y)∣≥ε0.\exists \varepsilon_0 > 0\ \forall \delta > 0\ \exists x, y \in \R : \abs{x - y} < \delta \text{ but } \abs{f\p{x} - f\p{y}} \geq \varepsilon_0.∃ε0​>0 ∀δ>0 ∃x,y∈R:∣x−y∣<δ but ∣f(x)−f(y)∣≥ε0​.

    Let ε0>0\varepsilon_0 > 0ε0​>0 be as in the negation. Applying the assumption to δ=1n\delta = \frac{1}{n}δ=n1​, we get sequences (xn)n,(yn)n\p{x_n}_n, \p{y_n}_n(xn​)n​,(yn​)n​ such that ∣xn−yn∣<1n\abs{x_n - y_n} < \frac{1}{n}∣xn​−yn​∣<n1​ and ∣f(xn)−f(yn)∣≥ε0\abs{f\p{x_n} - f\p{y_n}} \geq \varepsilon_0∣f(xn​)−f(yn​)∣≥ε0​ for all n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N.

    By the squeeze theorem, an≔yn−xn→0a_n \coloneqq y_n - x_n \to 0an​:=yn​−xn​→0, but

    ∣fan(yn)−f(yn)∣=∣f(xn)−f(yn)∣≥ε0,\abs{f_{a_n}\p{y_n} - f\p{y_n}} = \abs{f\p{x_n} - f\p{y_n}} \geq \varepsilon_0,∣fan​​(yn​)−f(yn​)∣=∣f(xn​)−f(yn​)∣≥ε0​,

    which implies

    0<ε0≤sup⁡x∈R∣fan(x)−f(x)∣,0 < \varepsilon_0 \leq \sup_{x \in \R} \abs{f_{a_n}\p{x} - f\p{x}},0<ε0​≤x∈Rsup​∣fan​​(x)−f(x)∣,

    so fanf_{a_n}fan​​ cannot converge to fff uniformly.

Exercise 3.2.2(i)(ii)

  1. Let (f(n))n=1∞\p{f^{\p{n}}}_{n=1}^\infty(f(n))n=1∞​ be a sequence of functions from one metric space (X,dX)\p{X, d_X}(X,dX​) to another (Y,dY)\p{Y, d_Y}(Y,dY​), and let f ⁣:X→Y\func{f}{X}{Y}f:X→Y be another function from XXX to YYY. Show that if f(n)f^{\p{n}}f(n) converges uniformly to fff, then f(n)f^{\p{n}}f(n) also converges pointwise to fff.
  2. For each integer n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, let f(n) ⁣:(−1,1)→R\func{f^{\p{n}}}{\p{-1, 1}}{\R}f(n):(−1,1)→R be the function f(n)(x)≔xnf^{\p{n}}\p{x} \coloneqq x^nf(n)(x):=xn. Prove that f(n)f^{\p{n}}f(n) converges pointwise to the zero function 000, but does not converge uniformly to any function f ⁣:(−1,1)→R\func{f}{\p{-1, 1}}{\R}f:(−1,1)→R.
Solution.

  1. Given x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, we have

    dY(f(x),f(n)(x))≤sup⁡z∈XdY(f(z),f(n)(z))→n→∞0d_Y\p{f\p{x}, f^{\p{n}}\p{x}} \leq \sup_{z \in X} d_Y\p{f\p{z}, f^{\p{n}}\p{z}} \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} 0dY​(f(x),f(n)(x))≤z∈Xsup​dY​(f(z),f(n)(z))n→∞​0

    since f(n)→ff^{\p{n}} \to ff(n)→f uniformly. Thus, by the squeeze theorem, f(n)(x)→f(x)f^{\p{n}}\p{x} \to f\p{x}f(n)(x)→f(x), so since xxx was arbitrary, this shows that f(n)→ff^{\p{n}} \to ff(n)→f pointwise.

  2. For any x∈(−1,1)x \in \p{-1, 1}x∈(−1,1), we have ∣x∣<1\abs{x} < 1∣x∣<1, so we have ∣x∣n→0\abs{x}^n \to 0∣x∣n→0. This shows that f(n)→0f^{\p{n}} \to 0f(n)→0 pointwise. Now suppose for the sake of contradiction that f(n)→ff^{\p{n}} \to ff(n)→f uniformly for some function f ⁣:(−1,1)→R\func{f}{\p{-1, 1}}{\R}f:(−1,1)→R. By (a), f(n)→ff^{\p{n}} \to ff(n)→f pointwise, so by uniqueness, f(n)f^{\p{n}}f(n) converges to 000 uniformly. However, for all n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N,

    sup⁡x∈(−1,1)∣xn−0∣=1\sup_{x \in \p{-1, 1}} \abs{x^n - 0} = 1x∈(−1,1)sup​∣xn−0∣=1

    (it's clear that ∣xn∣≤1\abs{x^n} \leq 1∣xn∣≤1 and conversely, lim⁡x→1−xn=1\lim_{x\to1^-} x^n = 1limx→1−​xn=1). In particular, sup⁡x∈(−1,1)∣xn−0∣↛0\sup_{x \in \p{-1, 1}} \abs{x^n - 0} \not\to 0supx∈(−1,1)​∣xn−0∣→0, so xnx^nxn cannot converge uniformly to 000, which is a contradiction.

Exercise 3.2.4

Let fn ⁣:X→Y\func{f_n}{X}{Y}fn​:X→Y be a sequence of bounded functions from one metric space (X,dX)\p{X, d_X}(X,dX​) to another metric space (Y,dY)\p{Y, d_Y}(Y,dY​). Suppose that fnf_nfn​ converges uniformly to another function f ⁣:X→Y\func{f}{X}{Y}f:X→Y. Suppose that fff is a bounded function; i.e., there exists a ball B(Y,dY)(y0,R)B_{\p{Y,d_Y}}\p{y_0, R}B(Y,dY​)​(y0​,R) in YYY such that f(x)∈B(Y,dY)(y0,R)f\p{x} \in B_{\p{Y,d_Y}}\p{y_0, R}f(x)∈B(Y,dY​)​(y0​,R) for all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X. Show that the sequence fnf_nfn​ is uniformly bounded; i.e., there exists a ball B(Y,dY)(y0,R)B_{\p{Y,d_Y}}\p{y_0, R}B(Y,dY​)​(y0​,R) in YYY such that fn(x)∈B(Y,dY)(y0,R)f_n\p{x} \in B_{\p{Y,d_Y}}\p{y_0, R}fn​(x)∈B(Y,dY​)​(y0​,R) for all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X and all positive integers nnn.

Solution.

Since fff is bounded, there exist y0∈Yy_0 \in Yy0​∈Y and R>0R > 0R>0 such that f(x)∈BY(y0,R)f\p{x} \in B_Y\p{y_0, R}f(x)∈BY​(y0​,R) for all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X. Since f(n)→ff^{\p{n}} \to ff(n)→f uniformly, there exists N∈NN \in \NN∈N such that

sup⁡x∈XdY(f(x),f(n)(x))<1.\sup_{x \in X} d_Y\p{f\p{x}, f^{\p{n}}\p{x}} < 1.x∈Xsup​dY​(f(x),f(n)(x))<1.

Thus, for any x∈Xx \in Xx∈X and n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, we have

dY(f(n)(x),y0)≤dY(f(n)(x),f(x))+dY(f(x),y0)<1+R.d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{x}, y_0} \leq d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{x}, f\p{x}} + d_Y\p{f\p{x}, y_0} < 1 + R.dY​(f(n)(x),y0​)≤dY​(f(n)(x),f(x))+dY​(f(x),y0​)<1+R.

In other words, f(n)(x)∈BY(y0,R+1)f^{\p{n}}\p{x} \in B_Y\p{y_0, R + 1}f(n)(x)∈BY​(y0​,R+1) for all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X and n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N. It remains to handle f(1),…,f(N−1)f^{\p{1}}, \ldots, f^{\p{N-1}}f(1),…,f(N−1). For each 1≤n≤N−11 \leq n \leq N - 11≤n≤N−1, there exist yi∈Yy_i \in Yyi​∈Y and Ri>0R_i > 0Ri​>0 such that f(i)(x)∈BY(yi,Ri)f^{\p{i}}\p{x} \in B_Y\p{y_i, R_i}f(i)(x)∈BY​(yi​,Ri​) for all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X. Set

R′=max⁡1≤i≤N−1dY(yi,y0)+max⁡1≤i≤N−1Ri+(R+1).R' = \max_{1 \leq i \leq N - 1} d_Y\p{y_i, y_0} + \max_{1 \leq i \leq N - 1} R_i + \p{R + 1}.R′=1≤i≤N−1max​dY​(yi​,y0​)+1≤i≤N−1max​Ri​+(R+1).

Let x∈Xx \in Xx∈X and n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N. If 1≤n≤N−11 \leq n \leq N - 11≤n≤N−1, then

dY(f(n)(x),y0)≤dY(f(n)(x),yn)+dY(y0,yn)<max⁡1≤i≤N−1Ri+max⁡1≤i≤N−1dY(yi,y0)≤R′.\begin{aligned} d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{x}, y_0} &\leq d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{x}, y_n} + d_Y\p{y_0, y_n} \\ &< \max_{1 \leq i \leq N - 1} R_i + \max_{1 \leq i \leq N - 1} d_Y\p{y_i, y_0} \\ &\leq R'. \end{aligned}dY​(f(n)(x),y0​)​≤dY​(f(n)(x),yn​)+dY​(y0​,yn​)<1≤i≤N−1max​Ri​+1≤i≤N−1max​dY​(yi​,y0​)≤R′.​

Otherwise, if n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, then

dY(f(n)(x),y0)<R+1≤R′.d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{x}, y_0} < R + 1 \leq R'.dY​(f(n)(x),y0​)<R+1≤R′.

Thus, in all cases, we have shown f(n)(x)∈BY(y0,R′)f^{\p{n}}\p{x} \in B_Y\p{y_0, R'}f(n)(x)∈BY​(y0​,R′), as desired.
